question_content.barrons:question: The author approves of all of Lind’s experimental methodology EXCEPT his

barrons:choices.barrons:choice: division of the sick seamen into six separate but corresponding groups
criteria for the selection of possible cures to test
selection of subjects all suffering from the same ailment
choice of remedies then in favor with naval surgeons
provision of identical dietary conditions for each group

question_content.barrons:explanation:
Choices 2 and 4.

The author remarks that the weakness of Lind’s work was that "the six possible cures that he compared were presumably selected empirically from those currently favored by ships’ surgeons." Thus, he disapproves both of Lind’s criteria for the selection of possible cures to test and of his choice of remedies then in favor with naval surgeons.

Choice 1 is incorrect. The author approves of Lind’s division of the sick seamen into six separate but corresponding groups: he writes that the experiment "had obvious commendable features," and remarks that Lind "selected six groups that were as similar as possible at the beginning of the experiment."

Choice 2 by itself is incorrect. The author remarks that the weakness of Lind’s work was that "the six possible cures that he compared were presumably selected empirically from those currently favored by ships’ surgeons." Thus, he disapproves of Lind’s criteria for the selection of possible cures to test. However, there is another answer choice of which he disapproves.

Choice 3 is incorrect. The author approves of Lind’s selection of subjects all suffering from the same ailment: he writes that the experiment "had obvious commendable features," and remarks that Lind "selected six groups that were as similar as possible at the beginning of the experiment."

Choice 4 by itself is incorrect. The author remarks that the weakness of Lind’s work was that "the six possible cures that he compared were presumably selected empirically from those currently favored by ships’ surgeons." Thus, he disapproves of Lind’s choice of remedies then in favor with naval surgeons. However, there is another answer choice of which he disapproves.

Choice 5 is incorrect. The author approves of Lind’s provision of identical dietary conditions for each group: he writes that the experiment "had obvious commendable features," and remarks that Lind "maintained them (the groups) throughout under the same general environmental and dietary conditions."
